title: Sudan Army Says RSF Attacks Key Port With Drones for First Time
content: Sudan’s army said its opponents used drones to strike a military airbase and other locations in Port Sudan, the first apparent attacks of that kind on the Red Sea city in the two-year civil war.

title: Fed’s Powell Is About to Defy Trump and Hold Rates Steady
content: Things are getting awkward for the Federal Reserve.

title: Etihad Is Squeezing Outsized Luxuries Into its Smallest Aircraft
content: When Etihad Airways received its first Airbus SE A380 jets a good decade ago, the airline furnished the front of the giant double decker with a veritable luxury playground it called the Residence, a three-room layout featuring a double bed, living area and shower cubicle — all with a personal butler on hand.

title: China’s Early Dividend Payouts to Help Ease Yuan’s Price Swings
content: Chinese companies listed in Hong Kong are bringing forward dividend payments to the second quarter, a move that may smooth out yuan volatility over the year.

title: Buffett Exit to Lift Energy Executive Abel to Berkshire CEO
content: Greg Abel built one of the largest energy businesses in the US under mentor Warren Buffett. Now, he’ll try to fill the shoes of the world’s most famous investor.

title: Shell Is Studying Merits of BP Deal as Rival’s Stock Slumps
content: Shell Plc is working with advisers to evaluate a potential acquisition of BP Plc, though it’s waiting for further stock and oil price declines before deciding whether to pursue a bid, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Short Sellers Bet Against Private Credit Lenders
content: Hedge funds are betting that trade wars, a shrinking economy and rising strain among borrowers will begin to hit private credit in the US. So far, the gamble’s paying off.

title: Buffett to Step Down Following Six-Decade Run Atop Berkshire
content: Warren Buffett, who built Berkshire Hathaway Inc. into a business valued at more than $1.16 trillion and himself into a celebrity billionaire renowned for his investing acumen and witticisms, will step down at year-end after six decades atop the conglomerate.

title: Saudis Double Down on Seismic OPEC+ Shift to Sink Oil Prices
content: As Saudi Arabia’s Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman addressed his OPEC+ counterparts on a video call to ratify the group’s second huge supply increase in as many months, he invoked a surprising historical precedent: the 1973 oil embargo imposed by major OPEC nations that sent crude prices soaring.

title: Reading Agrees to Sale of Football Club to Redwood Holdings
content: Reading Football Club said US financier Rob Couhig’s Redwood Holdings Ltd. has agreed in principle to buy the club.

title: Singapore Ballot Boxes Sealed After Polls Closed
content: Singapore’s People’s Action Party were off to a strong start in Saturday’s election, according to sample counts showing the party that has ruled the city-state for six decades well ahead of the opposition in more than two dozen voting districts. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Berkshire’s Geico Has Cut Thousands of Jobs in Turnaround Effort
content: Berkshire Hathaway said its auto insurer Geico has cut tens of thousands of jobs as part of its efforts to turn around a business that’s lagged behind peers.

title: Berkshire’s Warren Buffett Says Trade Can Be an ‘Act of War’
content: Berkshire Hathaway Chief Executive Officer Warren Buffett addressed US President Donald Trump’s tariff policies at the company’s annual meeting in Omaha, saying trade “should not be a weapon.”

title: PM Anthony Albanese Speaks After Winning Second Term
content: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese speaks after winning second term saying "Today the Australian people have voted for Australian values." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: How Will Trump’s Tariffs Influence Trade?
content: President Donald Trump believes his tariffs will make the US flush with cash, but there are nuances to his plan. Nobel Laureate Paul Romer believes that in order to have a fair trade policy, it must benefit all Americans. Former US Trade Representative Susan Schwab doesn’t believe reciprocal tariffs are a means to an end, and doesn't think we’ve ever had free trade.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese Wins Second Term
content: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was re-elected in Saturday’s vote with an expanded majority, projections show, becoming the nation’s first leader in 21 years to win back-to-back elections. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Stock Market Bull Charges On, Question Is When It Meets the Bear
content: The stock market is on a heater. After rising for nine straight sessions and gaining 10% in that time, the S&P 500 Index closed out the week on its longest winning streak in more than 20 years, recouping all of its losses since April 2, when President Donald Trump launched his global trade war.

title: Big Oil Isn’t Budging on Output as OPEC+ Supply Hike Looms
content: The largest western oil producers are mostly sticking with their growth plans for now, despite a 16% decline in crude prices during April and a decision by OPEC+ to crank up output in June.

title: Fed Bashing for a President Is a Fool's Game, Summers Says
content: Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers stresses that the Fed should hold interest rates steady as President Donald Trump continues to pressure the central bank, and criticizes Treasury Secretary Bessent's call for the Fed to cut rates. Columbia Law School’s Kathryn Judge dissects how the Fed has evolved. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Larry Summers Says White House Is Giving ‘Misguided Guidance’
content: On the eve of FOMC meetings next week, President Donald Trump and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent have both urged rate cuts.

title: OPEC+ Agrees Another Supply Surge in June to Deepen Oil Rout
content: OPEC+ agreed to surge output again in June, as the group’s leaders continue an accelerated revival of supply aimed at punishing over-producing members that has sent crude prices plunging.

title: Netflix Co-CEO Says India Investment Has Had $2 Billion Impact
content: Netflix Inc. said its production investment in India generated $2 billion in economic impact from 2021 through last year, underscoring the country’s growing importance for the US streaming giant.

title: Nigeria Incurs $9 Billion Derivatives Loss to Clean Up Reserves
content: The Nigerian central bank had a 13.9 trillion naira ($9 billion) loss on the settlement of overdue derivatives contracts in 2024 as it tried to prune foreign currency liabilities on its balance sheet and restore investor confidence on available measures to support the naira.

title: India’s Largest Bank Plans to Raise $3 Billion in Share Sale
content: State Bank of India plans to raise 250 billion rupees ($3 billion) through new shares and this fiscal year, marking the first equity raising by the state lender in seven years.

title: Pakistan Conducts Missile Test as Tensions Flare With India
content: Pakistan’s military said it tested a long-range missile amid rising tensions with neighbor India following an attack that killed more than two dozen people, mainly tourists, in India-controlled Kashmir.

title: Before Blackout, Spain’s Power Grid Investment Lagged Solar Boom
content: Spain’s nationwide blackout this week is putting a spotlight on the potential vulnerabilities in its system that could offer lessons for other countries, as rapid electrification and the shift to clean energy place new demands on grids across the world.

content: More signs emerged in a wave of reports this week that global manufacturing is buckling from President Donald Trump’s trade war.

content: Any doubts about the People’s Action Party’s ability to continue dominating Singapore’s politics after six decades of rule were put to rest with Saturday’s election result.

title: Romanian President Vote Highlights Far-Right Risk: What to Watch
content: Romanians will have another go at a presidential election on Sunday after the shock victory of a far-right fringe candidate last year prompted accusations of Kremlin interference and the cancellation of the ballot.

title: Lawrence Wong: Who is Singapore’s Prime Minister?
content: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong won his mandate on Saturday to lead the trade-dependent city into the tariff chaos wrought by US President Donald Trump. He’ll also need to navigate the shifting demands of voters frustrated by high prices as he embarks on his first elected term as leader.

title: Bolivia Senate President Rodriguez Plans to Run for President
content: Bolivia’s Senate President Andronico Rodriguez said he will run for president in the August election, emerging as perhaps the most likely candidate to rally left-wing voters.

title: Swarthmore Ends Campus Protest With Colleges Under Scrutiny
content: Swarthmore College called in police to break up a pro-Palestinian camp on its grounds, saying the protest had drawn scrutiny by federal officials.

content: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum said she rejected an offer by President Donald Trump to send US troops across the border to help combat drug trafficking.

title: Yemen Names New Prime Minister After Mubarak Resigns
content: Yemen’s head of the Presidential Leadership Council, Rashad Al-Alimi, appointed Salem Saleh bin Buraik as the new Prime Minister, according to the government-run Saba news agency.

title: Singapore’s Ruling Party Keeps Majority in Victory for Wong
content: Singapore’s ruling party secured a convincing victory in Saturday’s election as voters worried about rising costs and a worsening global economic climate rallied behind incumbent Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in his first electoral test since taking office a year ago.

title: Trump Draws Criticism After Posting an AI Image of Himself as the Pope
content: NEW YORK (AP) — President Donald Trump posted an artificial intelligence-generated image of himself dressed as pope as the mourning of Pope Francis continues and just days before the conclave to elect his successor is set to begin. Trump's action drew rebukes from a group representing Catholic bishops in New York and among Italians.

title: Five Takeaways From PAP’s Singapore Election Victory: TOPLive
content: In a third victory for incumbent political parties in a week, Singapore’s People’s Action Party won a supermajority in Saturday’s election, delivering a strong mandate for Lawrence Wong in his first election as prime minister.

title: Gabon’s New President Sets Path Back to Constitutional Order
content: Gabon will hold parliamentary elections on Sept. 27, the country’s newly elected president, Brice Oligui Nguema, said Saturday.

title: Serbian President Vucic Stable After Falling Ill in US
content: Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic is in a stable condition after falling ill during a visit to the US, where he experienced chest pain related to high blood pressure, his doctors said on Saturday.

title: Rubio’s Ascendance Masks Bigger Question of Who Has Trump’s Ear
content: A jolt of staff upheaval this week made Marco Rubio the first person in 50 years to hold the top two national security jobs in the US government, the culmination of a journey from his role as Donald Trump’s rival for the presidency to one of his most prominent aides.

title: Singapore Ruling Party Starts Strong in Early Sample Vote Count

title: Australia’s PM Albanese on Track for Biggest Victory Since WWII

content: The Republican-led push to abolish the US estate tax has provoked opposition from a seemingly surprising source: financial advisers the wealthy pay to manage their money and keep down their taxes.

She believes the sector will continue its upward trajectory and will provide a strong basis for investments and creativity. Abudu speaks to Bloomberg's Jennifer Zabasajja on the latest episode of Bloomberg Next Africa. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: What’s Next for Australia’s PM Albanese After a Historic Re-Election
content:
Australian PM Anthony Albanese has been re-elected for a second term — the nation’s first leader in more than 20 years to win back-to-back elections.

Ben Westcott explains the challenges that lay ahead for the Labor Party hero. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Investors Eye Nigeria's Cinema Industry
content: After Netflix and Amazon stopped commissioning original films, Nigeria’s financiers spotted an opportunity to break into the industry. Nollywood, as Nigeria’s freewheeling filmmaking industry is called, is a booming business. Hard figures are difficult to come by, but the country produces the second-highest number of movies in the world every year after India, and at least a million people are estimated to work directly or indirectly in the sector. Jennifer Zabasajja reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Why Are Deepfakes Everywhere? Can They Be Stopped?
content: The internet is awash in deepfakes — audio, pictures or video made using artificial intelligence tools in which people appear to do or say things they didn’t, be somewhere they weren’t, or that change their appearance. Some involve nudification, where photos are altered to depict someone unclothed. Other deepfakes are deployed to scam consumers, or to damage the reputations of politicians and other people in the public eye.

title: Harrods Latest UK Retailer to Battle Against Hacking Attacks

title: GM Cuts Workers at Canada Truck Plant, Citing Trade Turmoil
content: A General Motors Co. assembly plant in Canada that makes pickup trucks mostly for export to the US will cut down to two shifts from three because of the trade war.

title: China Hints at Possible Thaw With US in Weighing Trade Talks
content: China said it is assessing the possibility of trade talks with the US, the first sign since Donald Trump hiked tariffs last month that negotiations could begin between the two sides.

title: ECB Can Be Optimistic on Inflation, Guindos Tells Die Presse
content: The European Central Bank can be confident on returning inflation to the 2% goal, according to Vice President Luis de Guindos.

title: Carney, Trump Prepare to Talk Trade and Security at White House
content: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney said he’ll meet with US President Donald Trump in Washington on Tuesday, their first face-to-face encounter since he won an election in part because of an anti-Trump message.

title: Namibia Joins Central Banks’ Gold Rush to Hedge Against Shocks
content: Namibia’s central bank plans to join others that are adding gold to their foreign-exchange reserve mix as a buffer against global uncertainty that’s intensified since US President Donald Trump slapped tariffs on its trading partners.

title: Trump’s Auto Tariff Relief Shields USMCA Auto Parts From 25% Tax
content: President Donald Trump’s revised auto tariff plan continues — at least for now — an exemption for parts that comply with the free trade agreement spanning North America, a concession desperately sought by industry.

title: Barclays Pushes Forecast for Next Fed Cut to July From June
content: Economists at Barclays delayed the timing of their predication for the Federal Reserve to cut rates to July, from June, following a stronger-than-expected payroll report.

title: Global Manufacturing Activity Contracts for First Time This Year
content: Global manufacturing activity contracted for the first time this year in April, dragged down by shrinking orders and employment.

title: Zambia, Zimbabwe Court Investors to Revive $5 Billion Hydro Dam
content: Zambia and Zimbabwe are ramping up efforts to secure investment for the long-delayed $5 billion Batoka Gorge hydropower project, as they revive a controversial plan to potentially source water from the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: US Employers Add 177,000 Jobs, Solid Pace in Face of Uncertainty
content: US job growth was robust in April and the unemployment rate held steady despite deep uncertainty over President Donald Trump’s trade policies, which economists expect will dent hiring plans over the coming months.

title: Auto Workers Welcome Trump’s Tariffs, No Matter What’s Happening on Wall Street
content: Some auto workers like James Benson Jr. are all-in on President Donald Trump’s trade war — and they don’t mind if it causes some short-term pain for both Wall Street and Main Street.

title: US Treasury Sanctions Cartel Leader in Fuel Theft Crackdown
content: The US Treasury Department announced sanctions on three Mexican nationals and two Mexican companies involved in fuel theft and smuggling by the Cartel Jalisco Nueva Generacion.

title: Bank of Ireland Starts to See a Pause in Foreign Investments
content: Some of Bank of Ireland Group Plc’s corporate and foreign direct investment customers paused investments in the first quarter because of global business uncertainty, according to the lender.

title: Chile Economic Activity Bounces Back on Mining Output Surge
content: Chile’s economic activity bounced back in March on a surge in mining, while other sectors posted more muted gains as government officials and the central bank warn of a turbulent global outlook ahead.

title: Here Are the Takeaways From the US Jobs Report for April
content: Here are the key takeaways from the US employment report for April, released Friday:

title: China Shipping Loophole Closed by Trump, Raising Prices for US Consumers
content: Small-value packages shipped to the US from China will no longer be exempted from tariffs starting Friday, when President Donald Trump’s move against an exception he called a “big scam” takes effect.

title: US Jobs Strength Unlikely to Move Fed as Trade War Looms
content: A worker moves spools of copper wire between rod breakdown machines. Photographer: Justin Hamel/Bloomberg

title: Food Inflation Heats Up But Some Relief May Be in Store
content: As worries about the impact of tariffs on the economy and consumer demand persist, there’s a sliver of good news on the horizon: The World Bank expects food commodity prices to actually drop.

title: The Ricochet Effect From Trump’s Trade War
content: I’m Craig Stirling, a senior editor in Frankfurt. Today we’re looking at the inflation impact on Europe of Chinese exports. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.

title: Tariff Concerns Drive Global Food Prices to Two-Year High
content: Global food prices rose to a two-year high in April, a sign that tariff uncertainty is starting to put a squeeze on trade.

title: Saudi Chemicals Giant Posts Another Surprise Earnings Loss
content: Saudi chemicals giant Sabic suffered a surprise loss in earnings for a second straight quarter, adding to signs the company is struggling to cope with market uncertainty and broad industry headwinds.

title: Fired Kohl’s CEO Said to Have Had History of Mixing Relationship With Work
content: The decision to oust Buchanan raised questions about what the company knew about a relationship that is said to have had long blurred professional lines.

title: Etihad Is Squeezing Outsized Luxuries Into its Smallest Aircraft
content: When Etihad Airways received its first Airbus SE A380 jets a good decade ago, the airline furnished the front of the giant double decker with a veritable luxury playground it called the Residence, a three-room layout featuring a double bed, living area and shower cubicle — all with a personal butler on hand.

title: Google Can Train Search AI With Web Content After AI Opt-Out
content: Google can train its search-specific AI products, like AI Overviews, on content across the web even when the publishers have chosen to opt out of training Google’s AI products, a vice-president of product at the company testified in court on Friday.

title: NTSB Probing Aborted Landings at Reagan Due to Army Chopper
content: The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating aborted landings by two flights into Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport due to a nearby US Army Black Hawk helicopter that was traveling to the Pentagon.

title: American Airlines Sues Chicago Over O’Hare Gates for United
content: American Airlines Group Inc. sued the city of Chicago in a fight with rival United Airlines Holding Inc. over valuable gate space at O’Hare International Airport.

title: Jaguar Land Rover Restarts Shipments to US After Tariffs Pause
content: UK automaker Jaguar Land Rover has resumed shipments of vehicles to the US after pausing them following the announcement of tariffs by President Donald Trump’s government.

title: Big Oil Isn’t Budging on Output as OPEC+ Supply Hike Looms
content: The largest western oil producers are mostly sticking with their growth plans for now, despite a 16% decline in crude prices during April and a decision by OPEC+ to crank up output in June.

title: Netflix Co-CEO Says India Investment Has Had $2 Billion Impact
content: Netflix Inc. said its production investment in India generated $2 billion in economic impact from 2021 through last year, underscoring the country’s growing importance for the US streaming giant.

title: Buffett to Step Down From Berkshire Hathaway at Year-End
content: Warren Buffett Photographer: Scott Eells/Bloomberg

title: UK Ring-Fencing Rules Prompt Rare Public Row Among Bank Bosses
content: The top bosses at the UK’s biggest banks don’t often tussle in public but new proposals about the future of the country’s crisis-era ring-fencing rules have chief executives squaring off.

title: JetZero’s Triangle-Shaped Jet On Track to Fly By Late 2027
content: JetZero Inc., the start-up aiming to take on planemakers Airbus SE and Boeing Co., is on track to fly the first full-scale model of its manta ray-shaped jetliner by late 2027, executives said Friday.

title: United to Cut Newark Operations as FAA Issues Snarl Flights
content: United Airlines Holdings Inc. will cut 35 daily round trips at Newark Liberty International Airport after Federal Aviation Administration technology failures and an air traffic controller shortage snarled flights for a full week.

title: Transportation Department Plans to Cut Workforce at End of May
content: Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy told employees in a town hall Friday that he’s planning to reduce the department’s workforce at the end of this month.

title: US Approves $3.5 Billion Weapons Sale to Saudi Arabia
content: The US approved the sale of weapons worth an estimated $3.5 billion to Saudi Arabia ahead of a planned visit by President Donald Trump to the Gulf kingdom this month, as Washington seeks to strengthen ties with a key partner and ratchet up pressure against Iran.

title: US Approves Up to $350 Million in Ukraine F-16 Training, Support
content: The US State Department approved F-16 fighter-jet training and services for Ukraine worth up to $350 million, signaling that the White House will keep supporting Kyiv in the fight against Russia despite President Donald Trump’s impatience to end the war.

title: I Squared Nears Deal for $5 Billion Matterhorn Pipeline
content: A consortium led by I Squared Capital is considering buying Matterhorn Express Pipeline in a deal that would value the Texas natural gas conduit at about $5 billion including debt, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Nike, Adidas Call on Trump to Exempt Footwear From Tariffs
content: A trade association representing footwear producers has asked the Trump administration to consider tariff exemptions for its products, saying the levies will drive up the cost of shoes in the US and cause businesses to shutter.

title: Sun Country Airlines CEO Says Demand Woes Risk Extending Into Summer
content: The pace of air travel early this summer is uncertain as consumers who drove a sharp decline in demand last quarter remain worried about the economy, the top executive of Sun Country Airlines Holdings Inc. said.

title: Chevron Cuts Buybacks and Exxon Sits Tight as Oil Plunges
content: Chevron Corp. will reduce share buybacks this quarter after oil prices tumbled, indicating that President Donald Trump’s trade war is hurting a key US industry he pledged to help.

title: GM Cuts Workers at Canada Truck Plant, Citing Trade Turmoil
content: A General Motors Co. assembly plant in Canada that makes pickup trucks mostly for export to the US will cut down to two shifts from three because of the trade war.

title: Shein’s London IPO Stalled Amid US Tariff Fallout
content: Shein Group Ltd.’s initial public offering plan has slowed to a crawl as the retailer assesses the impact of US tariffs on its business and awaits regulatory approvals, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: US Measles Cases Hit 935 as RFK Jr. Pushes Treatment Study
content: The US reported 51 new measles infections on Friday, an increase of 6% from the previous week as Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the nation’s top health official, pushed for research into unproven treatments.

title: Trump Administration Proposes Cutting $6 Billion From NASA’s Budget
content: President Donald Trump’s proposed budget for next year calls for sweeping cuts to many of NASA’s programs, including a plan to phase out the agency’s Boeing Co.-made moon rocket, reduce crews and operations on the International Space Station and gut science initiatives.

title: Trump’s Auto Tariff Relief Shields USMCA Auto Parts From 25% Tax
content: President Donald Trump’s revised auto tariff plan continues — at least for now — an exemption for parts that comply with the free trade agreement spanning North America, a concession desperately sought by industry.

title: Retailer Claire’s to Defer Debt Interest Payments Amid Tariff Tensions
content: Claire’s Stores Inc. is choosing to defer interest payments on its debt as a way to conserve cash as the US-China trade war roils retailer supply chains.

title: Norway’s Equinor Offloads Stake in Brazilian Oil Field for $3.5 Billion
content: Equinor ASA agreed to sell its 60% stake in the Peregrino oil and gas project off the Brazilian coast to PRIO SA for $3.5 billion, as the Norwegian energy explorer seeks to streamline international operations. Rio de Janeiro-based PRIO gained.

title: Xcel CEO Says AI Power Needs Boost Chance of New Big Nuclear
content: It’s been more than a decade since the US last broke ground on a large-scale nuclear power plant that came online. Xcel Chief Executive Officer Bob Frenzel is raising the idea that it’s time to start again.

title: Auto Workers Welcome Trump’s Tariffs, No Matter What’s Happening on Wall Street
content: Some auto workers like James Benson Jr. are all-in on President Donald Trump’s trade war — and they don’t mind if it causes some short-term pain for both Wall Street and Main Street.

title: Medical Equipment Makers Stryker, Becton Eye Price Hikes to Offset Tariffs
content: Medical equipment makers including Stryker Corp. and Becton Dickinson & Co. are looking to pass on at least some of the estimated tariff hit to customers by raising prices.

title: Your AI-powered credit card will shop for you now
content: We're not lazy enough, so Visa and Mastercard have hired AI personal assistants to do our shopping

title: Elon Musk, DOGE team credit fed workers for helping trim waste, fraud
content: Elon Musk and his DOGE team expressed their gratitude Thursday to the federal employees partnering with the cost-cutting agency as they work around the clock to eliminate wasteful spending and modernize the workforce.

title: Legislators propose upgraded tax credit for short line rail maintenance
content: New legislation would upgrade a federal tax credit short line railroads depend on for infrastructure spending.

title: Subscription scams surge across hundreds of fake websites - how to stay safe
content: Subscription scams are popping up on social media sites, attempting to trick users out of their credit card information.

title: Trump praises Gov. Gretchen Whitmer while at Michigan air base
content: Trump announced a new series of fighter jets for the Selfridge Air National Guard base in Michigan, giving credit in part to Democratic Gov. Gretchen Whitmer.

title: Can't make your credit card payments this May? Here's what to do.
content: At risk of falling behind on your credit card bills this May? Here's what to do before your debt and fees spiral.

title: Best Credit Cards for Cashback & Rewards in 2025 [Expert Picks]
content: In this guide, we break down the best credit cards for cashback and rewards in 2025, handpicked for U.S. consumers looking to get the most out of every dollar

title: 7 Simple Steps to Improve Your Credit Score Fast
content: If you are wondering how to improve your credit score fast, the key lies in taking targeted actions that have immediate impact. Start by paying off

title: ‘King of All Pimps’ — who recruited then-NY Gov. Eliot Spitzer hooker Ashley Dupré — claims his reputation was trashed by murder claim
content: A notorious pimp who took credit for recruiting Ashley Dupré, the hooker whose tryst with then-Gov. Eliot Spitzer ended the "Luv Guv's" career, claims in a lawsuit that a YouTuber has ruined his rep.

title: The U.S. states where auto loan delinquency is rising the most
content: Falling behind on car payments can lead to repossession and long-term credit damage

title: SEC’s Anti-Fraud Public Service Campaign Warns Investors About Relationship Investment Scams
content: The SEC’s Office of Investor Education and Advocacy unveiled its anti-fraud public service campaign, which warns investors about the devastating impact relationship investment scams can have on their financial future.

content:

title: By Building Wealth, Investors Power U.S. Economy
content: April is Financial Literacy Month, and the SEC is encouraging investors to utilize the agency’s saving and investing resources on Investor.gov.

content:
The Securities and Exchange Commission today voted to end its defense of the rules requiring disclosure of climate-related risks and greenhouse gas emissions.

title: SEC Crypto Task Force to Host Four More Roundtables
content: The SEC&#039;s Crypto Task Force will hold four more roundtables in its ongoing series discussing crypto asset regulation.

content:
The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the agenda and panelists for the March 27 roundtable on artificial intelligence in the financial industry.

content: The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced a six-month extension of the compliance dates for amendments adopted in September 2023 to the Investment Company Act “Names Rule,” which addresses fund names likely to mislead investors about a fund’…

content: The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed settled charges against registered investment adviser Momentum Advisors LLC, its former managing partner Allan J. Boomer, and its former chief operating officer and partner Tiffany L. Hawkins, for…

content: The Securities and Exchange Commission is providing extensive guidance and resources to assist filers with upcoming access and account management enhancements to the security of the agency’s Electronic Data Gathering, Analysis, and Retrieval (EDGAR)…

title: SEC Crypto Task Force to Host Roundtable on Security Status
content: The SEC&#039;s Crypto Task Force will host a series of roundtables to discuss key areas of interest in the regulation of crypto assets.

content:

content:
The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the members of the Crypto Task Force staff, which is advising the Commission on matters related to crypto.

title: SEC to Host Roundtable on Artificial Intelligence
content: The SEC will hold a roundtable discussion on artificial intelligence and examine the risks, benefits, and governance of it in the financial industry.

content:
The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced that the Commission has filed a joint stipulation with Coinbase Inc. and Coinbase Global Inc. to dismiss the ongoing civil enforcement action against the two entities.

title: How Embedded Finance Is Quietly Transforming Startup Business Models
content: Traditional banks are having a hard time keeping up with customers' expectations for embedded finance. In this guest commentary, Arthur Azizov, founder and investor at B2 Ventures, provides some answers to what customers want and why they want it.

title: Tariffs And The Venture Value Chain: A Blip Or Long-Term Pain?
content: Guest author Rohit Yadav takes us on an exploration of the value chain — VC fundraising, startup fundraising and exits — to see how tariffs are driving both direct and indirect impacts.

title: The Longer IPOs Delay, The Less Likely Debuts Will Happen
content: Over the past couple weeks, as we’ve seen Klarna, StubHub and others delay scheduled pre-IPO roadshows, it appears markets are to blame. But how will delays affect a company's success when it finally makes its debut?

title: Crypto Startup Ripple Buys Hidden Road For $1.25B
content: Crypto payments firm Ripple is acquiring brokerage house Hidden Road for $1.25 billion in one of the biggest M&A deals ever in crypto.

title: Tariffs, Volatility And The Startup Exit Dilemma
content: Even seasoned startup investors today face what feels like a novel turn of events: a potential recession and increasing exit uncertainty due to government-induced volatility, writes guest author Don Butler of Thomvest Ventures.  For an ecosystem that has long awaited the return of robust exit volumes, the uncertainty in the markets sparked by tariffs couldn’t come at a worse time.

title: CoreWeave Closes Flat In First-Day Trading
content: Shares of CoreWeave closed flat at $40 on their first day of trading on the Nasdaq today. Shares had opened at $39 on Friday, a day when the Nasdaq sank 2.7%.

title: CoreWeave Shrinks IPO
content: Cloud computing startup CoreWeave is cutting the size of its IPO, looking for a valuation closer to $23 billion than the roughly $30 billion it had originally targeted.

title: Want To Sell Your Startup Quickly To A Strategic Buyer? Consider This From The Get-Go
content: Whether buying a startup or selling one, there are plenty of steps that need to be considered, writes guest author Murat Abdrakhmanov. In this commentary he provides recommendations to help both buyer and seller reach their strategic and financial goals.

title: The Most-Active, Spendiest Startup Investors Are Lagging Greatly In Lucrative Exits
content: The most active, highest-spending startup investors are leading a lot of large new rounds lately. When it comes to exits, however, things look much, much slower. We used Crunchbase data to examine IPO and M&A exits since 2023 for six firms that regularly top our active lead investor rankings.

title: Forget Startups. Maybe The Most Adaptable Companies Are Those That Last Centuries
content: Building a lasting business can take an exceedingly long time, but it's nothing compared to hundreds of well-known, successful organizations and brands that can trace their roots back not in years or decades but in centuries. Here's a look at a few of them.

title: With Turo Withdrawal, A Slim IPO Pipeline Gets Thinner
content: Peer-to-peer car rental platform Turo became the latest venture unicorn to withdraw plans for a public offering.

title: Adapting The IPO Roadmap For Today’s Market
content: The path to IPO has become slower and more arduous for companies looking for an exit, writes Fiunder Shield's COO Carl Niedbala. In this guest commentary he lays out some effective measures to help founders be prepared when an opportunity presents itself.

title: Q1 Global Startup Funding Posts Strongest Quarter Since Q2 2022 With A Third Going To Massive OpenAI Deal
content: Overall, the first quarter of 2025 marked the strongest one for venture investment since Q2 2022. Funding was up 17% quarter over quarter from the $96 billion reached in Q4 2024.

title: How To Leverage Your Pre-Seed Funding For Rapid And Successful Growth
content: After the pre-seed round is a time for a startup to plan for securing follow-on investments, says guest author Sergei Bogdanov, who shares early-stage funding advice to founders regarding what to do as well as what not to do.

title: Most-Active Startup Investors Spent More In Q1
content: The busiest venture backers upped their game in the recently ended first quarter. Among the 14 most-active post-seed investors, a majority backed more deals in Q1 2025 than they did a year ago.

title: Europe’s VC Funding Stayed Flat In Q1, Even As Healthcare Added A Third
content: Europe’s venture funding plateaued at $12.6 billion in Q1 2025 — flat quarter over quarter and year over year, Crunchbase data shows. Without the sort of outsized AI funding rounds seen in North America in the first quarter, the continent’s share of global funding also fell.

title: Latin America Startup Funding Fell Sequentially In Q1
content: Latin America startup investment declined sequentially in the first quarter of this year, driven by a drop in later-stage dealmaking. Even so, funding was above the depressed levels seen a year ago, and early-stage dealmaking showed signs of strength.

title: SignalFire Closes On $1B To Invest In Applied AI
content: Bay Area-based SignalFire, a data-driven venture firm, has raised $1 billion for its fifth and largest fund, which it will invest in applied AI companies.

title: North America Startup Investment Spiked In Q1 Due To OpenAI, But Seed And Early Stage Fell
content: Despite several big deals that buoyed the numbers, North America early- and seed-stage investment declined to multiquarter lows in Q1, and reported round counts fell across stages.

title: Q1 Global Startup Funding Posts Strongest Quarter Since Q2 2022 With A Third Going To Massive OpenAI Deal
content: Overall, the first quarter of 2025 marked the strongest one for venture investment since Q2 2022. Funding was up 17% quarter over quarter from the $96 billion reached in Q4 2024.

title: 7 Deadly Pitch Deck Sins, According To A VC
content: VC firms receive thousands of pitch decks a year and a typical investor will spend no more than two to three minutes assessing each one. In this guest commentary, investor Michael Tefula of Ada Ventures shares seven of the biggest mistakes that are more likely to land your pitch in the “no, thanks” rejection bin.

title: Far Fewer Seed-Stage Startups Are Graduating To Series A — Raising The Risk Of Failure
content: Companies stalled at the seed stage might be sacrificing growth to get to breakeven, which could further hinder their ability to show the traction needed to get to a Series A.

title: Seed Funding Rose In These Spaces
content: Even as overall seed-stage investment declined in 2024, a few areas saw big gains. This includes the obvious category — AI — as well as a subset of sectors largely focused on automating things that humans currently do. We take a look at four top picks.

title: Seed Funding Fell Hard In These Sectors
content: U.S. seed-stage investment actually declined a bit last year, particularly in a handful of industries including several beset by disappointing performance of startups funded in recent prior years. We take a look.

title: Q1 Global Startup Funding Posts Strongest Quarter Since Q2 2022 With A Third Going To Massive OpenAI Deal
content: Overall, the first quarter of 2025 marked the strongest one for venture investment since Q2 2022. Funding was up 17% quarter over quarter from the $96 billion reached in Q4 2024.
